Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Collaborative Research: Algorithms and Data for High-Frequency, Real-Time Anomaly Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The rapidly burgeoning amount of digital data from Internet and mobile-enabled communications can offer low-cost and high-resolution views into human behavior across areas such as health and socio-economics. Personally-generated data from Internet and mobile-connected sources offer unique insight, capturing aspects of human behavior that would be taxing or impossible to quantify through other data sources. Moreover, the data is often available in real time and can be linked to specific locations. This research project addresses the statistical challenges inherent in using such unstructured spatio-temporal data sets for detection of anomalous events.

Such data requires new statistical approaches to pre-process and extract forms from the data that can reliably be used for event detection. Further, the continuous nature of the data means that what constitutes anomalous behavior depends on the time-scale and on the type of underlying event. This project aims to develop 1) approaches for generating relevant features from social media data that account for the observational nature of the data and can be used in spatio-temporal models of real-world behavior and 2) a new multi-scale approach to modeling dependence structures that uses new information to continuously refine the model and accurately assess anomalies. The approach in this project is both suited to and harnesses the continuous and observational nature of social media data. The research will be validated on empirical data sets, demonstrating practical utility. It is anticipated that the results will be applicable to further the use of publicly-available geospatial data sources and understand human dynamics that are not measurable through other means.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To address statistical challenges associated with using digital data from Internet and mobile communications, for aggregate use in real-world scenarios the specific goals of this project were: 1) Feature extraction methods from social media data that account for data that is missing at random and not representative across time or space; and 2) An interpretable, multiscale perspective that strategically directs model complexity based on the difficulty of the underlying prediction task.

The intellectual merit contributions of this project centered on development of methods to address aspects of real-time, precisely geo-located Internet-facilitated new media sources, and moreover the integration of these in modelling approaches that leverage these features. First, we developed methods to address aspects of real-time social media data through efficient usability with sparse data, and an approach that adapts as new data arises in real time. We also generated novel methods for spatio-temporal analyses from observational data; from content-based clustering of social media data, as well as topographically constraining such clusters to more recent work in which we are using regression and spatial-dependance and methods to identify the impact of multiple interventions with high spatial and temporal resolution. Finally, we expanded work beyond social media data, working on feature extraction methods from satellite imagery data. We developed a pipeline that includes a deep learning model for acquisition of deep landscape features from high-dimensional satellite imagery and integration of those in a disease prediction model. In sum, the work developed methods to extract usable information from Internet-based observational data sources, and developed modelling methods that incorporate such data for forecasting with different objectives.

Broader Impacts of this project are at multiple levels. Dissemination of findings to diverse scientific communities (computer science including computer vision and machine learning, as well as infectious disease/public health and other communities) via publications and presentations has exposed communities to the opportunities of interdisciplinary work and specifically benefits in augmenting modeling. Talks given by PI Chunara and graduate students at conferences, and department seminars have also been attended by undergraduate and graduate students (amongst faculty and industry members) and provided exposure to those in computer science, statistics and bioinformatics to potential applications of their research. Finally, the methods developed here, being relevant to application areas in a variety of domains, have been used to shape education efforts that will reach multiple disciplinary communities, specifically through a graduate level course at NYU and organization of a workshop focused on real-world data challenges at The International Conference on Learning Representations.
